thread.title: Bell: Joe Philbin was always in over his head with Dolphins
thread.title_full: Bell: Joe Philbin was always in over his head with Dolphins

title: Bell: Joe Philbin was always in over his head with Dolphins
text:
USA TODAY Sports' Tom Pelissero breaks down the Dolphins' decision to fire Joe Philbin and what's next for the team. USA TODAY Sports
Joe Philbin went 24-28 in three-plus years with the Dolphins. (Photo: Thomas J. Russo, USA TODAY Sports)
Maybe Stephen Ross finally had some sort of epiphany in London after witnessing yet another embarrassing performance by his Miami Dolphins under the watch of Joe Philbin.
I know what I would have thought, if in Ross' ownership shoes, as I cringed at the sight of the New York Jets defense making a mockery of Philbin's offense with their exotic blitzes. Something like a flashback — I could have had that guy running my team.
The inglorious end of the Philbin Era as Dolphins coach came with a cruel irony: His final game came against a Jets team coached by Todd Bowles, who was the Miami interim coach passed over (along with another finalist, now-San Diego Chargers coach Mike McCoy) when Ross and his brain trust hand-picked Philbin in 2012.
Guess they got that one wrong.
USA TODAY
Miami Dolphins fire coach Joe Philbin after 1-3 start
Now Bowles is off to a rousing start with the Jets (3-1) after finally landing a head coaching job. McCoy won a playoff game in his first year as a first-time head coach with the Chargers in 2013.
Philbin? He never had a winning season.
His case doesn't illustrate the risk in hiring a first-time coach — there are many successful examples, like Mike Tomlin and Sean Payton — as much as it underscores the skill in picking the right person.
Of course, it can't be easy. Teams bungle coaching hires all the time. But Ross, a relatively new owner, needs to learn through this experience while contemplating who fits the job and why.
USA TODAY
6 coaching candidates the Dolphins could consider to replace Joe Philbin
It's early, but the Atlanta Falcons' new hire, Dan Quinn, is sure living up to his reputation as a high-energy lightning rod who inspires his team. Conversely, Philbin was derided in NFL circles as a "high school gym coach," which isn't exactly an endorsement of the respect he earned from his players.
Not every coach needs to spew fire and brimstone. A big personality hardly guarantees a championship (see my man Rex Ryan). Bowles, for example, has a low-keyed public persona but has earned major props for his high football IQ and ability to relate to players.
Philbin wasn't ready for his opportunity. But what memories he leaves behind.
He cut a washed-up Chad Ochocinco on HBO's Hard Knocks , making a high-character statement against domestic violence.
USA TODAY
50 things we learned in Week 4 of the NFL season
Philbin went into damage-control mode after the bullying scandal that featured since-departed linemen Richie Incognito and Jonathan Martin while providing a statement about how a coach can be so clueless about his locker room culture. Philbin seemed even more unwitting for the double standard that was ultimately revealed: Before the bullying episode came to light, he'd put Incognito on the team's leadership council, even after an incident at a charity golf course that involved inappropriate physical contact with a female volunteer.
Then there was the pathetic regression of quarterback Ryan Tannehill and the offense that surrounds him. Philbin came to Miami after serving as the Green Bay Packers offensive coordinator, which associates him with Aaron Rodgers and Mike McCarthy.
But Philbin did not bring the Green Bay magic to South Beach.
He was destined to go, given the lifelessness of his team. The back-to-back blowout losses to AFC East foes (the Buffalo Bills thumped the Dolphins at home 41-14 in Week 3) were signs that things were not getting better, even though Philbin maintained Sunday that the season could still be salvaged. Miami has been outscored 37-3 in the first quarter this season, which says a lot about not having a team ready to play.
While the offense tanked, the once-formidable defense has caved, too, which is why coordinator Kevin Coyle may be next to go. The Dolphins rank last against the run, last in sacks and 30th in total yards allowed — and that's with the $114 million addition of Ndamukong Suh. Miami's three consecutive losses came against quarterbacks Blake Bortles, Tyrod Taylor and Ryan Fitzpatrick — who are not to be confused with Tom Brady, Peyton Manning and Rodgers.
USA TODAY
NFL Week 4 overreactions: Should Cowboys weigh QB change?
Still, some of the tales that surfaced Monday added substance to the typical, new-coach mantra expressed by interim boss Dan Campbell. Tannehill, team leader and all, reportedly had beefs with practice squad players who were picking him off in practice — and Philbin supposedly told his JV group to lighten up on the quarterback to help boost his confidence. That's no way to develop a competitive environment.
Maybe Campbell, now the NFL's youngest coach at 39, can fix it. But history shows that coaching moves made this early in the season never turn into a quick ticket to the playoffs.
The bottom line is that the Dolphins had better get it right the next time they hire a coach.
***
Follow NFL columnist Jarrett Bell on Twitter @JarrettBell
